Four welterweights compete for the remaining semifinal spots in two thrilling back-to-back fights. Also: the animosity between the coaches goes too far at the weigh-ins; Dana White determines the semifinal matchups.
Season 24 opens.
The international fighters try to fit in at the house with mixed results; the coaches get on each other's nerves; and the No. 5 and 12 seeds battle it out in a classic striker vs. grappler matchup.

A member of Team Benavidez expresses hostility towards coach Cejudo; and the coaches continue to challenge each other's patience. Also: The most feared fighter in the house goes up against a seasoned veteran in the tournament's fourth fight of round one.

Eric Shelton talks with Matt Schnell about becoming a father at an early age; the coaches review their past fights against Demetrious Johnson, offering advice to the fighters; and two flyweights face off for a spot in the second round.
A fighter gets emotional while describing his upbringing; and the fighters take a break to watch UFC 200 at the house. Then, a ground specialist takes on an all-around threat in a Round 1 matchup.
Team Benavidez goes paddleboarding during a break from training. Then, the seventh fight of Round 1 features two experienced fighters known for ending fights in the first round.

A fighter's comment following his loss causes friction, which nearly erupts in a fistfight; and the coaches go head-to-head in a golf challenge. Then, two flyweights face off in the final Round 1 clash.
The fighters enjoy a surprise party at the house; and controversy arises after Benavidez invites both teams to train with his head coach, Duane Ludwig. Then, the first fight of Round 2 is contested.

Eric Shelton and Tim Elliott argue about their different approaches to the fight game; and Hiromasa Ogikubo struggles with a language barrier. Then, two flyweights square off in the second fight of Round 2.
T.J. Dillashaw joins Team Benavidez as a guest coach to help prepare the fighters. Then, the third and fourth fights of Round 2 determine who moves on to Round 3.

Season 23 opens with both light-heavyweight men and strawweight women facing off in 16 elimination bouts. Coaches Joanna Jedrzejczyk and Claudia Gadelha take in the fights alongside Dana White, then pick their teams from the winners.
The fighters move into the house, and the start of training brings animosity between the coaches. Then, in the first preliminary fight, a dangerous striker takes on a familiar opponent.

Helen Harper is distraught after getting injured in practice; Cory and Khalil have a donut-eating contest at the house; Dana White rewards the fighters with a night of video gaming; and two strawweights face off for the first time this season.

Joanna lashes out at her team for a perceived lack of effort during training; and a Red Team rallying cry rubs Team Claudia the wrong way. Then, a classic striker vs. grappler clash determines a semifinal spot.

Season 20 winner Carla Esparza pays a visit and helps Team Joanna with training; and Abdel Medjedoub gets a call from home that puts his future in the competition in jeopardy. Then, two strawweights battle for a spot in the semifinals.

Dana chooses to intervene when Abdel's personal problems threaten his future in the competition. Meanwhile, a losing fighter eyes a second chance. Then, in the fifth preliminary fight, a determined young competitor faces a skilled veteran.
Smack talk by Joanna at the fight announcement irritates Team Claudia; and Khalil gets emotional on the anniversary of his father's death. Then, two strawweights duel for a spot in the semifinals.
A painful injury hinders one fighter's ability to train ahead of the semifinals. Then, a dangerous striker and a seasoned pro battle in the last light-heavyweight matchup.
Cory gets the test results from his neck injury, and the coaches start training for their upcoming title fight. Then, two more strawweights clash for the last semifinals spot.

A bombshell is dropped as Joanna and Claudia compete in the biggest coaches challenge in "Ultimate Fighter" history. Then, in the first light-heavyweight semifinal, two friends battle it out for a spot in the finale.

Conor McGregor and Urijah Faber meet as coaches in the opener of Season 22, a U.S. vs. Europe competition. Qualifying fights are held to determine the eight lightweight fighters from each continent who will enter the house and battle for a UFC contract.

The fighters move into the house and begin training; and Dana reveals an unexpected twist to the competition. Then, one of Team USA's most seasoned fighters takes on a European powerhouse in the first preliminary fight.

The tension rises as Conor tries to get under Uriah's skin and dares him to fight TJ Dillashaw. Two fighters step into the octagon for the second preliminary bout and a coach completely loses it as he watches the fight unfold.

After a frustrating fight, a coach loses his cool on a fighter in front of the team; Urijah and Conor argue over coaching styles; a member of Team Faber skips practice; and the third preliminary match eliminates another fighter from the competition.
Pressure mounts for one of the fighters as Conor and Urijah prep their squads ahead of the fourth preliminary fight. Also: Both teams get a chance to relax during a night out with the coaches.

An unorthodox fighter from Team Faber faces one of the top competitors of Team Europe in the fifth preliminary fight; UFC bantamweight champ T.J. Dillashaw arrives to help Urijah, but when Conor calls him a traitor, all hell breaks loose.
Two Team Faber fighters come face-to-face in a drunken confrontation. Then, an explosive American fighter and a tough European face off in the sixth preliminary fight.
The seventh and eighth preliminary fights are contested.
McGregor and Faber face off in the coaches' challenge; an American fighter takes on an experienced European in the ninth and final preliminary fight; the coaches argue over the quarterfinal matchups.

An unexpected turn of events brings a fighter back into the competition; a European powerhouse goes head-to-head with a Team Faber fighter in the first quarterfinal; and it's a matchup of strength vs. technique in the second quarterfinal.

The series' first-ever gym vs. gym edition kicks off in the Season 21 premiere, as welterweights from American Top Team and the rival Blackzilians battle. The teams will share a house but train separately while seeking home-gym advantage for the fights.
Tempers flare when the team owners clash at the weigh-in. Meanwhile, the pressure of the competition takes a toll as team infighting turns ugly.
American Top Team deals with some personal demons. Meanwhile, the Blackzilians are forced to make tough decisions.
Tempers flare on both sides, and a medical emergency threatens the future of one fighter and his team.
One fighter struggles to cope with his latest loss. Meanwhile, two fighters with a shared history are ready for a rematch.
American Top Team rallies around their fighters, while the Blackzilians look to keep going strong.
American Top Team struggle to regain their fire as the Blackzilians face the threat of losing one of their own.
The teams select their next fighters, setting the stage for an unexpected rematch.
The pressure is on both teams to choose their fighters wisely for the first 100-point fight.
Dan and American Top Team find themselves at a critical turning point in the competition. With the end in sight, Glenn and the Blackzilians make their plan to crush their opponents, once and for all.

The Season 20 opener introduces the 16 female fighters battling to become the UFC's first strawweight champ. After coaches Anthony Pettis and Gilbert Melendez pick teams for this first all-female season, the fighters move in and the opening bout is held.
Hard training takes its toll on Team Melendez, while the Team Pettis fighters grow frustrated with their coaching. Then, Joanne Calderwood faces Emily Kagan for a spot in the quarterfinals.

One fighter receives devastating news, while Team Melendez's Heather Clark becomes an outcast after a silly game turns raunchy. Then, Jessica Penne locks horns with Lisa Ellis in the third preliminary fight.
Tensions escalate between Heather Clark and her Melendez teammates; Urijah Faber acts as guest coach for Team Pettis; Carla Esparza and Angela Hill scrap for a quarterfinals spot.

An injury forces one fighter out of the competition and gives another a second shot. Elsewhere, the Team Melendez fighters question the severity of Heather Clark's nagging knee issue. Then, Clark and Felice Herrig renew their rivalry in the fifth prelim.
Tecia's return to competition angers some of the fighters; Aisling struggles to get Dana's attention prior to the sixth preliminary fight, which pits her against Angela Magana.

The Team Melendez rift grows, and Heather receives some shocking news that quiets her teammates. Then, both teams get a visit from members of the U.S. Women's National Soccer Team; and Rose Namajunas battles Alex Chambers in the seventh preliminary bout.
Tensions boil over at a pool party after a group of Team Melendez fighters decide to kick Tecia Torres out of their room. Then, Torres battles Bec Rawlings in the final preliminary fight.
Aisling Daly gets a surprise visit from Conor McGregor, and the fighters visit Harley-Davidson Boot Camp. Then, Daly takes on Jessica Penne in the second quarterfinal.
Sixteen up-and-coming middleweights and 16 promising light heavyweights face off in a day of elimination fights, hoping to secure a spot in the competition for a shot at a coveted UFC contract.

Sixteen hopefuls move into the house, ready to pursue their dream of becoming The Ultimate Fighter. At weigh-ins, coaches BJ Penn and Frankie Edgar must pull their heated fighters apart. Later, two fighters prep for a vicious battle.
Having secured two wins in the first two matchups, Team Penn looks to continue the streak. Meanwhile, a rivalry develops between two light heavyweights.

On the heels of Tim Williams' surprising loss, BJ gives his team a lecture on the risks of over-training. Then, former boxer Josh Clark tries to get momentum back in Team Penn's favor, as he faces skilled wrestler Corey Anderson of Team Edgar.

The teams are tied heading into the third middleweight matchup of the season. Roger Zapata takes on Ian Stephens and when the fight is finished, Dana reacts explosively to one of the most controversial bouts in TUF history.

Tensions boil over at the house in the wake of Roger Zapata's controversial win, causing a rift between the teams. And in the sixth preliminary fight, wrestler Patrick Walsh of Team Edgar tries to get the momentum back in their favor.

Team Penn's number one middleweight Mike King takes on the powerful underdog, Eddie Gordon of Team Edgar. Only one will win, earning a spot in the semifinals. And, BJ Penn and Frankie Edgar make a splash in this season's coaches' challenge.

The fighters take a field trip to the Harley-Davidson Boot Camp. Cocky Matt Van Buren of Team Edgar and Chris Fields of Team Penn bring their rivalry to the Octagon in the last preliminary fight. Then, Dana announces the semifinal matchups.

The semifinals kick off with a middleweight battle between the highly touted Irishman, Cathal Pendred, and the underdog from New York, Eddie Gordon. But first, Dana brings the semifinalists to the MGM Grand, and delivers an inspiring speech.

Ronda Rousey and archrival Miesha Tate arrive at the gym to coach the first-ever coed season of The Ultimate Fighter. When the dust settles, eight men and eight women have won spots in The Ultimate Fighter house.

Team Tate is in the hunt for its second win as grappling specialist Chris Holdsworth takes on Rousey's number one male pick, Chris Beal. The team's cohesion is threatened when Cody Bollinger accuses Julianna Pena of leaking their fight picks.

On Father's Day, Rousey visits the Ultimate Fighter house to drop off presents to the fathers. But not even a gift can lift the spirits of the homesick Cody Bollinger, who sobs privately for the company of his daughter and wife.

Tate Teammates Sarah Moras and Julianna Pena are matched up in the first women's semifinal. Hoping that the annoying Pena will be defeated, most fighters support Moras. Only one will claim a spot in the finale.
Season 18 concludes at the finale in Las Vegas, with Julianna Pena vs. Jessica Rakoczy; and Chris Holdsworth vs. David Grant. Gray Maynard vs. Nate Diaz headlines the card.

Season 17 begins with 14 winners of middleweight mixed-martial-arts preliminary bouts meeting coaches Jon "Bones" Jones and Chael Sonnen in Las Vegas. UFC President Dana White announces the first elimination fight.
Gilbert Smith faces Luke Barnatt in the first preliminary fight after the 14 middleweights move into the house and begin training; Smith gets emotional over his team's doubts about his readiness.
Uriah Hall vs. Adam Cella in the second preliminary bout; Coach Jones bonds with his squad on a visit to the house, while Coach Sonnen instills confidence in a fighter.
Collin Hart vs. Kevin Casey in the third preliminary fight. Also: the teams face off in a spontaneous rap battle at the house and a prank ignites smack talk that carries over to the weigh-in.

Josh Samman vs. Tor Troeng in the fifth preliminary; a fighter's attitude ignites a blowup at the house, causing a major rift in Team Sonnen; the fighters battle it out in a night of bowling, while Jon and Chael raise the stakes in a game of their own.

Presented by FX. One fighter cuts loose and another alienates himself when the guys get a night out at Hooters. A fighter s recurring leg pain lands him in the hospital. Then two fighters square off in the sixth Preliminary Fight.

Presented by FX. Jon Jones and Chael Sonnen face off in the most unique, and difficult, Coaches Challenge ever. After two fighters face off in the last preliminary fight, Dana forces the coaches to decide on the Wildcard matchup.
Two preliminary losers face off in the wild-card match; the teams unite for a Thanksgiving feast; a fighter calls out a competitor for the quarterfinals before Dana announces the matchups.
Quarterfinals begin with Kelvin Gastelum facing Collin Hart and Dylan Andrews taking on Luke Barnatt. Ronda Rousey and Mike Tyson make appearances.
Quarterfinals conclude with Josh Samman squaring off against Jimmy Quinlan and Uriah Hall facing Bubba McDaniel.
Presented by FX.
Coaches Roy Nelson and Shane Carwin pick squads and set up the first elimination fight. Meanwhile, vicious trash talk ensues just a day after the 16 welterweights move into the house.
Presented by FX. Tempers flare up in the house and training intensifies at the gym. Then two welterweights enter the Octagon for their Preliminary fight.

Presented by FX. Julian Lane lashes out after being disrespected by another fighter. Team Nelson wants more coaching from Roy. Coach Carwin chooses two Welterweights to collide in the 4th Preliminary fight.

Presented by FX. Coach Roy once again has a fighter choose his own opponent. Former UFC Light Heavyweight Champion Forrest Griffin drops in for training. The feud between Hill and Secor reaches its boiling point.

Presented by FX. James Chaney owns up to his unsportsmanlike conduct. One fighter turns against his friend. Mike Ricci takes on Nelson number one pick Dom Waters in the final preliminary fight. Dana White announces the Quarterfinal match-ups.

Presented by FX. Quarterfinal action continues as Joey Rivera and Jon Manley face-off to stay in the competition. The tension builds between Michal Hill and Mike Ricci before they enter the Octagon to unleash their aggression.
Team Cruz top pick Justin Lawrence faces Brazilian jiu-jitsu master Cristiano Marcello (Team Faber) in the second elimination bout. Also: Chris and John get into an altercation at the gym.

Presented by FX. "Episode 4." Sixteen promising mixed martial artists live together in The Ultimate Fighter house and train with opposing teams coached by UFC bantamweight champion Dominick Cruz and "The California Kid" Urijah Faber.

Presented by FX. "Episode 5." Sixteen promising mixed martial artists live together in The Ultimate Fighter house and train with opposing teams coached by UFC bantamweight champion Dominick Cruz and "The California Kid" Urijah Faber.

Presented by FX. "Episode 6." Sixteen promising mixed martial artists live together in The Ultimate Fighter house and train with opposing teams coached by UFC bantamweight champion Dominick Cruz and "The California Kid" Urijah Faber.

Presented by FX. Women's MMA Champion Ronda Rousey trains in the gym, then visits the TUF house. Cruz gets a surprise from Faber and his coaches. Underdog Chris Saunders faces Team Cruz number two Sam Sicilia in the seventh Preliminary Fight.

Presented by FX. "Become That Hero." Both teams head to a desert shooting range for an explosive Coaches Challenge. Andy Ogle takes on Mike Rio in the last preliminary fight, then Dana announces the first two quarterfinal matchups.

Presented by FX. Dana makes a surprise visit to the gym for a shocking announcement. Then the quarterfinal round kicks off with two fights: James Vick vs. Joe Proctor, and Justin Lawrence vs. Michael Chiesa.

Presented by FX. Chris Saunders battles through emotional issues as he prepares to face Vinc Pichel of Team Cruz. Then, in the last quarterfinal fight, Faber teammates square off when Andy Ogle takes on Al Iaquinta.
Presented by FX. The Ultimate Fighter is a reality TV show where 16 contestants live together and battle each other for a pair of Ultimate Fighting Championship contracts.

The Season 15 champion is crowned as Mike Chiesa faces Al Iaquinta in Las Vegas. Welterweights Jake Ellenberger and Martin Kampmann co-headline the card. Also: Max Holloway vs. Pat Schilling; Jonathan Brookins vs. Charles Oliveira.
Coaches Michael Bisping and Jason Miller select their teams from the crop of victorious featherweights and bantamweights. The first matchup is chosen and one fighter deals with severe anxiety issues.

Tempers flare during a Team Bisping practice. As the pranks ramp up a nasty rivalry brews between Akira Corassani and Dustin Neace, while John Dodson forms an alliance with members of the blue team. Then, two bantamweights square off in the second quarterfinal fight.
Mayhem hatches a sneaky plan to throw off Team Bisping; the Akira-Dustin rivalry turns ugly; Team Mayhem goes for its fifth straight win as two more featherweights face off.
An infected foot puts Roland's future in doubt; Akira and Diego teach TJ a painful lesson in training; after the last preliminary fight, Dana announces the semifinal matchups.
Bisping and Tiki execute their master prank; Akira's antics earn him a handful of new enemies before his featherweight semifinal against Dennis.
Miller and Bisping play a high-stakes game of air hockey on the roof of the Palms; T.J. Dillashaw and Dustin Pague in a bantamweight semifinal.

The season finale in Las Vegas, featuring Brandao-Bermudez (featherweights) and Dodson-Dillashaw (bantamweights) and a matchup of captains Jason Miller and Michael Bisping. Also: Tony Ferguson vs. Yves Edwards.
Season 13 gets under way with 14 welterweights vying for a six-figure UFC contract under the guidance of coaches Brock Lesnar and Junior Dos Santos.
A fighter quits after the pressure gets to be too much; coach Lesnar rouses his team for the second preliminary fight.
A coach must explain himself after an offensive post-fight comment; a team is suspicious of a member. Also: the third preliminary fight.
A fighter's toughness is questioned, due to his laid-back attitude; Matt Hughes visits a training session. Also: another preliminary match.
A coach comes down hard on his team after they post a third loss; a fighter's loyalty is questioned. Also: the fifth preliminary fight.
Injuries to a pair of teammates could doom their futures; a coach makes a major decision. Also: the final two preliminary bouts; the wild-card announcement.
The coaches' challenge is football themed; Dana White reveals the quarterfinal matchups. Also: the wild-card fight.
UFC fighter and U.S. Marine Brian Stann visits both teams; Clay battles an injury while taking on Ramsey.
Quarterfinals conclude with a rematch between Chuck and Zach, plus some hard hitting from Tony and Ryan. Semifinal fights are announced.
One of the fighters apologizes for disrespecting another, but the team doesn't buy his sincerity; two contestants face off for a spot in the finals.
Season 12 opens with 28 lightweight mixed-martial-arts fighters vying for a six-figure UFC contract under the tutelage of coaches Georges St-Pierre and Josh Koscheck.
Fourteen fighters move into the house and the matchup is set for the first preliminary fight of the season.

Alex Caceres annoys the other fighters with his bragging. An unimpressive training session forces Josh Koscheck to reprimand his squad. Legendary boxer Mike Tyson visits the gym on fight day as two more lightweights face off in the cage.
Sevak flies into a violent rage after Alex runs his mouth yet again. Two fighters prepare for a showdown in the Octagon, but one of them must first overcome pre-fight jitters.
An ill-advised prank makes Alex Caceres an outcast on his own team. Former UFC champion Chuck Liddell pays a visit to Team Koscheck. And two more lightweights face off in the Octagon.

Following the team's first win Koscheck talks smack to Michael Johnson, but then gets a dose of the same medicine from Cody McKenzie. And the fates of four fighters are determined in two lightweight matchups.

Koscheck and GSP step up to the plate for the Coaches Challenge. Last pick Dane Sayers and Judo champion Sako Chivitchian face off in the final preliminary fight. Then the wild card matchup is announced.

What starts out as smack talk turns into violence when Kos and Team GSP Medic Brad Tate put angry hands on each other. Stevens seeks redemption for his quick loss as he takes on Wilkinson in the Wild Card fight to fill the final slot in the Quarters.

The Quarterfinals get underway as Judo expert Sako Chivitchian of Team Koscheck takes on Team GSP's rising star, Jonathan Brookins. In the second fight skilled pupil Nam Phan faces Koscheck's trash-talking nemesis, Cody McKenzie.

In the last two Quarterfinal fights, Wild Card winner Aaron Wilkinson faces Team GSP elder statesman Kyle Watson. Then antagonistic teammates let their fists do the talking when Michael Johnson finally takes on Alex Caceres. And the Semifinal fights are announced.
Season 11 of the mixed-martial-arts reality competition begins as fighters vie for a six-figure UFC contract and cash. This season's teams are coached by Chuck Liddell and Tito Ortiz.
After the elimination fights, the 14 contestants move in to the house; Dana White confronts Liddell about his picks. Also: the first preliminary fight.

One fighter's dream comes to an abrupt end, opening the door for another to return. Team Ortiz struggles to find harmony during training. Two Middleweights leave it all in the cage for a slot in the Quarters.
One fighter accuses another of stealing his clothes, and they almost come to blows. Then two preliminary fights in one electrifying episode!
Wildcard speculation heats up, surgery sidelines a fighter, and Tito makes an uncharacteristic apology - all while 2 fighters prepare for the 5th Preliminary match-up.

A disgruntled fighter calls Tito out on his training techniques, and an injury sends another to the hospital. After Chuck and Tito face off in the coaches challenge, dodgeball, it's time for the sixth preliminary fight.

Nick Ring faces an uncertain future after his knee gives out in practice, comeback kid Seth Baczynski takes on rookie Joe Henle in the 7th Preliminary Fight, and Dana announces which 2 contestants will get a second shot in the Wildcard fight.

Kyacey Uscola and Kris McCray face off in the Wildcard fight. Dana visits the house and makes a shocking announcement that shakes up the competition. And then two fighters battle it out in the first Quarterfinal fight.
A team receives disturbing news from their coach; a ruling in the cage during the quarterfinals leads to a fight in the gym.
The result of the last quarterfinal bout shocks everyone; Dana makes an unprecedented decision.

This season of the Ultimate Fighter features heavyweights including superstar street fighter Kimbo Slice. Coaches Rampage Jackson and Rashad Evans continually argue before picking teams. The first preliminary fight takes place.
Rampage scrambles to teach Kimbo new skills, while Team Rashadâ€™s Roy Nelson is deemed "uncoachable." Team Rampage picks the next matchup, pitting size against skills.
Street-fighter Kimbo Slice races to learn all he can before he takes on former IFL champion Roy "Big Country" Nelson. And ex-NFL giant Marcus Jones causes trouble for Rampage.

A fighter keels over at the house, giving Kimbo hope for a comeback. A member of Team Rashad spills the beans on their fight strategy. And, two more heavyweights do battle as Team Rashad tries to extend its winning streak.

Zak Jensen faces mockery at the house and problems in training. Matt Mitrione tests Rashadâ€™s patience with an on-again/off-again shoulder issue. Rampage looks to break his losing streak in the fifth preliminary fight.

Rampage's hazing of Darrill Schoonover reaches a boiling point. After relentless teasing at the house, the fighters bet on which day Zak Jensen will finally snap. An injury puts a fighter's future in doubt.
Rampage and Rashad nearly come to blows. Matt Mitrione continues to cause problems for his team by betraying one fighter and then lashing out at another. The 7th preliminary fight takes place.
Matt Mitrione and Scott Junk return from their fight, battered and bruised. In the last preliminary fight, Jones faces Mike Wessel. The quarterfinal matchups are announced.
Mitrione wavers on whether he can fight, sparking speculation that Kimbo will return to the Octagon. Justin Wren and Roy Nelson square off in the first quarterfinal fight.

Questions continue about whether Matt Mitrione will fight, prompting a visit from Dana. Kimbo battles an injury with hopes of returning as a replacement. Teammates Brendan Schaub and Jon Madsen face off in the second quarterfinal fight.

For the first time ever, The Ultimate Fighter will be country vs. country as the United States takes on the United Kingdom. Dana White travels to England to watch 16 of Great Britain's toughest welterweights and lightweights fight their way onto coach Mic
With Team United Kingdom set, the US elimination fights get underway in Las Vegas. But the Americans stumble badly out of the gate, and Dana questions Team United States commitment.

The Americans and Brits move into the house as a fighter loses control and is ostracized. The last two Team USA members are decided when Kiel Reid and Jason Dent take on Frank Lester and Rob Browning.
Team USA grows tired of Bisping's cockiness and retaliate against the British team. After a clever strategy session and intense training it's finally time for the first US vs UK preliminary fight.
Team USAâ€™s infighting drives one American to form a bond with the Brits. Four fighters enter the Octagon for lightweight and welterweight bouts, and a coach fails to support his team member.
One fighterâ€™s nerves nearly incapacitate him. Another makes a pre-fight bet that ends in a bizarre payoff. Two fights in one episode continue the battle between nations.
Sudden injuries and infections leave everyone wondering who will be chosen to fight. Pierce becomes an outcast among his team. Bisping and Henderson go head-to-head in the Coaches Challenge.

A Team USA injury becomes a nasty infection, while one of the Brits struggles with a career-threatening mental problem. Then, after the next preliminary fight, Dana is forced to make a controversial decision that could blow the competition wide open.
Dana decides which Team USA fighter will replace Jason Pierce and take on David Faulkner in the final preliminary fight. And both teams collide in a heated argument over changing training times.
Dana adds a wrinkle to the semifinal matchups that infuriates the coaches. Team USA wonders if there's a traitor in their midst. And a bruising three round battle kicks off the semifinal fights.

The first eight fighters have earned their way into the house. A fight-ending injury, a no-contest and a light-headed fighter highlight an explosive first episode of the new season of The Ultimate Fighter!
The final eight fights take place, and an injury causes one fighter to postpone his dream of becoming the next Ultimate Fighter.
Coaches Nogueira and Mir pick their teams. A night of drinking brings out the good, the bad and the ugly in lightweight Junie Browning. The first preliminary light heavyweight match-up is fought.
Drunken debauchery puts the future of two lightweights in question, and after a grueling preliminary battle a fighter's rage causes chaos in the Octagon.
A coach steps in as the pranks go too far. Team Nogueira trains with UFC World Champion Anderson Silva before two more light heavyweights face off in the Octagon.

Rolando's black belt is called into question by the other fighters. An act of disrespect at the fight announcement injects more hatred between the teams, leading up to the most intense lightweight showdown yet.
Mir punishes his team with a grueling workout regimen. Nogueira has a blowout with a fighter whoâ€™s been talking smack. Two light heavyweights with opposing styles face-off in the Octagon.
The pranks at the house reach a new low. A fighter turns on his own teammate, offering up secret advice before a highly-anticipated lightweight bout.
A fighter gets knocked out at the house. Light heavyweight Kyle Kingsbury prepares to face Team Mir's number one pick, Krzysztof Soszynski.

Habitual hugger John Polakowski turns mean after Team Mir messes with his cereal. George Roop struggles with an injury before battling it out with John in the last of the preliminary fights. Dana and the coaches set the semifinal matchups.
Season 7 begins as 32 welterweight wannabes vie for a six-figure UFC contract. Season 1 champion Forrest Griffin coaches against Quinton "Rampage" Jackson.
The final elimination fights determine the 16 fighters who make it into the house; a brutal knockout silences the gym.
The coaches select their fighters and preliminary fights begin; a fighter's competition might be doomed due to a contagious skin condition.
Psychological games are played in one matchup, while youth battles experience in another showdown.
A Team Rampage fighter is targeted because of his obnoxious behavior; a controversial fight result infuriates one coach.
Both teams root for a fighter to be taken out in a fight; two nice-guy fighters turn vicious in the ring, stunning the rest of the fighters.

The final 3 preliminary fights are decided. In the first of two bouts, an inexperienced combatant faces an intimidating foe. And a battle between two heavy-hitters causes friction between the coaches.
The last of the preliminary fights is contested; the coaches must decide the quarterfinal matchups; Rampage's trash talking gets to Forrest.
A fighter has a voracious appetite before a quarterfinal match and that could prove detrimental to his chances of advancing.
The last of the quarterfinals are contested and the semifinals are set; one fighter has a meltdown.

UFC Welterweight champion Matt Serra and former champ Matt Hughes face off on the new season of The Ultimate Fighter. They split up 16 Welterweights into teams and the mind games begin. The first preliminary fight takes place.
Following his defeat, Joey threatens to leave the show and Serra goes ballistic. Hughes passes out bibles to his team. And the second preliminary fight takes place.
While Team Hughes prepares for the next fight, Team Serra gets down with sake and paint. Joeyâ€™s makes a final decision on whether heâ€™s going to stay or go.
After Billyâ€™s loss, Hughes takes out his anger on his team. One of the fighters threatens the production crew and Dana has to decide whether to kick him off the show.
A fighter receives tragic news from home. Mac blasts Bowmanâ€™s marital arts skills. Team Serra looks to win its fourth straight bout.
Team Hughes needs to win the next fight to have a say in the Quarter-final match-ups. Hughes teaches Dan a painful lesson. The sixth preliminary bout ends in controversy.
After suffering 5 straight loses, Hughes unleashes his wrath on his team. Team Serra turns on George. The 7th preliminary fight takes place.
Jon Koppenhaver is an explosive fighter with a troubled past. Tommy Speer is a Minnesota farm boy with overpowering strength. The two face off in the final preliminary fight.
Matt Serra makes his picks for the quarter-finals. Dana asks Team Serra to make a tough decision. Itâ€™s time for the first quarterfinal fight.
Four team Serra fighters are forced to fight each other in the quarter finals. Matt Serra decides he canâ€™t corner against members of his own team and Troy Mandaloniz feels ignored by his coach.
In the Season 5 opener, coaches Jens Pulver and BJ Penn evaluate 16 new fighters and pick their teams. Later, Cole Miller and Allen Berube face off in the Octagon.
BJ Penn has a surprise for Jens Pulver. Choice words cause an eruption at The Ultimate Fighter House. And another lightweightâ€™s dream of a UFC contract is crushed in the Octagon.
Team Pulver is 2-0 against Team Penn and BJ is not happy. Gabe continues to struggle with his weight making him a possible target for the next fight. And Team Pulver gets a surprise guest coach.

One fighter tries to take an easy path through the competition while another fighter disappoints his coach during crunch time. Team Pulver gets a surprise visitor and two more fighters step onto the battlefield.
Team Pulver has racked up four wins in a row against Team Penn. Still struggling with his weight, Gabe Ruediger is the likely target for Team Pulverâ€™s winning machine.
Itâ€™s two fights in one show. Itâ€™s Joe Lauzon vs. Brian Geraghty, followed by Rob Emerson vs. Corey Hill. Who will move on to the next round and gets a shot at the ultimate prize?
After five humiliating losses, BJ shakes things up and kicks one of his fighters off his team and the next two fights marks the end of the preliminary round of the competition.
Tensions at The Ultimate Fighter house reach an all time high and a fight breaks out. The quarterfinal match ups are announced. Who will be the first lightweight to make it into the semi-final round?

The battle for a spot in the semifinals continues.

Ultimate Fighter: The Comeback Begins introduces the sixteen mixed marital arts fighters who, over the course of the program, will compete against each other in a tournament in order to win the opportunity to fight for a world title.

Ultimate Fighter: Blood Bath continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. This episode features a showdown between middleweights Gideon Ray and Edwin Dewees.

Ultimate Fighter: Passing Guard continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. This episode features a showdown between Pete Spratt and Chris Lytle.

Ultimate Fighter: The Funk continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to a health scare that afflicts the fighters who live together in the same house, this episode features a showdown between middleweights Scott Smith and Travis Lutter.

Ultimate Fighter: Flip a Coin continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to the return of a fighter eliminated in a previous episode, this episode features a showdown between welterweights Mikey Burnett and Din Thomas.

Ultimate Fighter: Captain Miserable continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to an appearance by Rich Franklin, this episode features a showdown between middleweights Charles McCarthy and Pete Sell.

Ultimate Fighter: Drop to a Knee continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to an appearance by Rich Franklin, this episode features a showdown between welterweights Matt Serra and Pete Spratt.

Ultimate Fighter: True Colors continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to an appearance by Chuck Liddell, this episode features a showdown between light heavyweights Jorge Rivera and Patrick Cote.

Ultimate Fighter: Semi-Final Matchups continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. In addition to an appearance by Matt Hughes, this episode features a showdown between welterweights Chris Lytle and Din Thomas.

Ultimate Fighter: Carter vs. Serra continues the mixed martial arts tournament that will allow the winner to battle for a world title. This episode features a showdown between Matt Serra and Shonie Carter, who have met once before during the course of their careers.

The increasingly popular extreme fighting series Ultimate Fighter kicked off its third cycle of challenges with two former winners/rivals -- Ken Shamrock and Tito Ortiz -- heading up two teams of rough and tumble fighters to find out who will be champion. From this first episode, the men are put through their paces, physically and mentally, as they prepare to face-off.

Noah and Jesse face off in a light-heavyweight bout. To help Noah prepare for the fight, coach Ortiz has him train with a basketball to help him keep his hands up. Later, Kalib and Tait pop the ball with a knife as a joke.
Kendall and Solomon form an alliance and call themselves "Team Dagger." Also, Kendall faces Ross in a middleweight bout.
Team Shamrock worries they're not getting as much training as Team Ortiz, so they work out on their own without Ken. Later, Bisping faces Kristian in the Octagon.
Solomon faces Rory in the Octagon. Also: the fighters watch UFC 57; Ken and Tito exchange heated words.
Josh and Tait face off in the Octagon. Also: Matt gets injured in practice; Noah receives troubling news from home.
A former contestant returns to replace Noah; Josh shares an emotional story about his family; and Tait faces Josh in the Octagon.
Middleweights Ed and Danny face off in the Octagon.
Light heavyweights Matt Hamill and Mike Nickels face off in the Octagon.
The losers return to help the semifinalists train; Kalib faces Kendall in a semifinal bout; Ken and Tito compete in a game of pool for $10,000.

In the second-season opener, 18 more mixed martial artists are introduced and put through a series of grueling workouts. Later, one of the fighters quits and another is eliminated. UFC president Dana White is the host.
An alternate fighter arrives to make up for the house's early departures. Also: the teams compete in a "capture the dummy" challenge.
The teams compete in a swimming challenge in which they must tread water while working together to hold a team flag above the water.

The fighters compete in the "Hangman Challenge," in which three welterweights from each team climb onto an octagonal monkey-bar structure and fight their way to the center by using their legs to knock their opponents off the bars.
The fighters compete in a "Rock 'em Sock 'em challenge" in which they have to remove their opponents' socks. Later, Tom and Rashad face off in the Octagon.

The teams compete in the "Scarecrow" challenge in which a heavyweight stands with his hands raised while a welterweight rotates him as many times as possible. Also: Jason and Jorge face off in the Octagon.
The challenge: "Last Man Standing," in which the fighters try to remove opponents from a mud pit. Also: Seth and Dan face off in the Octagon.
One team surprises the other and attacks; two welterweights step up and battle it out.
A fighter goes on a binge after a win; another fighter discovers the difference between the camps.
The semifinal matchups are revealed; a fighter shows his killer instinct; one team is stunned by a loss.
The competitors are introduced. Willa Ford hosts.
Team Couture and Team Liddell test their strength, agility and will as they compete against each other.
One of the contenders must lose 20 pounds in 24 hours or face elimination. Also, two fighters battle it out in the octagon.
Two middleweights face off in the octagon. Also, Team Couture devises a new strategy; and UFC President Dana White throws a twist into the competition.
The two teams' night on the town turns violent, and contest rules are broken. Later, the responsible fighters are reprimanded.
Two contestants go into intensive training. Later, the teams rally around their fighters as an emotional conflict is settled in the octagon.
One of the teams struggles with discord among its members. Also, two of the strongest light-heavyweights are pitted against each other.
A fighter creates controversy by training with the opposing team. Also, a previously eliminated fighter gets another shot at the contract.
The light-heavyweights compete in a challenge. Also, the fighters suspect there is a thief in the house.
Dana has a surprising announcement. Also, the first semifinal fight ends dramatically.

Bourdain digs deep into the proud, often misunderstood culture of West Virginia, as he traverses a 5,000 foot mine, observes the demolition derby-like sport of rock-bouncing and dines on signature Appalachian dishes.
Bourdain returns to Uruguay after a decade away and finds a progressive nation in the midst of social change, but with evident fragments of its colonial past, most notably in its local cuisine.

Bourdain takes a wide-angle look at the culture and history of this country, heavily influenced by Europe and Russia, with guides musician of Armenian descent Serj Tankian, and historian-Armenian resident Richard Giragosian.
A look back at previous seasons features recaps, outtakes and commentary.
Bourdain tours the historically rich streets of Singapore and immerses himself in the vast array of multicultural foods found throughout this island city-state.
Bourdain and chef Eric Ripert embark on a ski-and-cheese-filled journey through the French Alps.
Bourdain travels to Nigeria and explores its food, music and rich cultural diversity.
Bourdain explores Pittsburgh's dining scene, which is part working class comfort food and part foodie boom town catering to a new high-tech industry.
Bourdain visits Sri Lanka to experience its reinvigorated people, savory food and vast landscapes.
Bourdain visits Puerto Rico and discovers delicious food and warm people, despite a seemingly insurmountable economic crisis.
A celebration of chef Jeremiah Tower's culinary career.
Bourdain immerses himself in the "boom or bust" city of Seattle.
Bourdain explores the largely untouched landscapes and colorful locals of Southern Italy.
Anthony Bourdain takes a look back at Season 8, featuring recaps, outtakes and commentary.
An alternative tour of Los Angeles by Bourdain focuses on the impact and contributions of its less photographed and often overlooked Latino communities.
Bourdain visits the coastal city of San Sebastian in the Basque Country, famous for its spectacular views and fresh seafood.
Bourdain visits Laos and experiences its enchanting scenery, distinctive aromas and exceptional food.
Bourdain discovers a hub of international cuisines and cultures in the Queens borough of New York City.
Bourdain travels to Antarctica to experience the serene beauty and mystery of the driest, coldest, windiest place on earth.
Bourdain takes his first journey to the Sultanate of Oman and finds a peaceful land of remarkable beauty that defies expectations.
A trip to Trinidad uncovers how the island has turned a history of colonialism and slavery into a non-stop celebration of multicultural food, music and good times.
Food takes center stage in this tour of Porto, Portugal, by Bourdain, whose local travel companions include his former Les Halles boss Jose Meirelles.

Inspired by Graham Greene's words "... whatever you're looking for, you will find here..." Bourdain joins the throngs of locals as he motorbikes through Vietnam's capital, traverses its rapidly changing cityscape, and indulges in its singular cuisine with president Barack Obama, who, over a dish of Bun Cha, shares personal stories and reflects on his own international travels. -- (C) CNN

Bourdain absorbs the tastes, sights and sounds of music city, from chef Josh Habiger's Catbird Seat and Bolton's famous hot chicken, to a night of cooking, drinking and rocking out with singer Alison Mosshart, and her bandmates. The episode features performances by The Kills, Dead Weather and Margo Price. -- (C) CNN

Michelin star chef, and all around good sport, Eric Ripert is introduced to China and Sichuan province by host and good friend Bourdain. Bourdain takes Ripert to the Sichuan province capital, Chengdu, testing his endurance with mouth-numbing, sinisterly spicy meals (like green peppercorn fish). They also visit the world's largest stone Buddha, seek out a local favorite rabbit head snack, and visit a legendary distillery for some Baijiu, a fermented sorghum wine. Ripert will never forget this trip. -- (C) CNN

Visiting London, post Brexit vote, Bourdain finds comfort in classic British cuisine including roast bone marrow at chef Fergus Henderson's famed restaurant St. John, Scotch eggs at Princess Victoria Pub with Nigella Lawson, and pig's trotter a la Pierre Koffman with chef Marco Pierre White at the Rudloe Arms, plus a meeting with revered artist Ralph Steadman at his studio. -- (C) CNN

Looking beyond oil, NASA, and football, Bourdain explores Houston's diverse cultures, taking in a Bollywood-style dance in a grocery store, a Quinceañera in suburban Pasadena, and the city's slab car parade, while making time for Viet-Bayou crawfish, East Texas barbecue, and a Congolese-Cajun stew. -- (C) CNN

Guided by world-renowned chef Masa Takayama, Bourdain's return trip to Japan begins with a tour of outdoor food markets in Kanazawa where they sample uni, steak-sized oysters, and grilled eel liver, followed by a conversation with an ex-geisha at her teahouse, and comes full circle with a special omakase experience at Tokyo's acclaimed Ginza restaurant, Sushi Ko, where Masa trained as an apprentice. -- (C) CNN

Bourdain explores the Brazilian heartland, known as the region where all the best cooks come from, and namesake to the country's mining history. Home to baroque architecture, lush hillsides and mineiro cuisine (influenced by Portuguese, African and Indigenous people), which includes frango ao molho pardo (broiled chicken served in a sauce made using its own blood), that the host samples during a traditional country meal. -- (C) CNN

Bourdain's trip to meat-centric Buenos Aires during the hot summer month of February, features a meal with chef Francis Mallmann at one of his favorite local spots, Don Carlito's, and an after-hours soccer match accompanied by Soledad Nardelli and the kitchen staff of Chila. -- (C) CNN

Bourdain's Roman holiday takes a cinematic turn, influenced by his tour guides, actress Asia Argento, screenwriter/director Abel Ferrara, and a host of larger than life Romans who take him inside a Rome for the locals. Bourdain shares drinks at the 'Friends Corner' trattoria in Lido di Ostia, dines a traditional Roman meal at Trattoria Morgana, eats pasta and watches an amateur boxing match in the suburbs, and takes a trip to the famed E.U.R zone built by Mussolini. -- (C) CNN
An alternative tour of Los Angeles by Bourdain focuses on the impact and contributions of its less photographed and often overlooked Latino communities.
Highlights of the best and most delicious moments from Season 6. Also: a preview of Season 7.
Bourdain visits Chicago's iconic Old Town Ale House, enjoys a home-cooked meal with rapper Lupe Fiasco and tours the famous Second City with performer Paul Jurewicz.
Bourdain visits the Crow reservation in Montana, hunts with podcast host Joe Rogan and eats dinner at Butte institution Lydia's Supper Club.
Zamir Gotta upstages Bourdain on a tour of the mountainous Eurasian country of Georgia, featuring food from Tbilisi, Batumi and Khurvaleti.
Bourdain explores West African culture in Senegal, with guides chef Pierre Thiam, journalist Ofeibea Quist-Arcton and famed musician Youssou N'Dour.
Bourdain visits Cologne, Germany, a city famous for its Kölsch beer, mett, and blood sausage.
Bourdain's trip to meat-centric Buenos Aires features a meal at famous local spot Don Carlito's and an after-hours soccer match.
Anthony Bourdain takes a look back at Season 7.
Season 6 begins with an exploration of Cuba, including visits to Havana and the music mecca of Santiago.
Bourdain and chef Eric Ripert visit Marseille, France, to experience its stew of cultures and cuisines, and its array of Corsican cheeses.
Bourdain visits Okinawa.
Bourdain visits the Bay Area of San Francisco to practice Brazilian Jiu Jitsu and heal through food.
Chef Marcus Samuelsson and his wife Maya take Bourdain on a tour of Ethiopia to experience the nation beyond the headlines.
Bourdain returns to Boreno after 10 years to enjoy chicken rendang and pork noodles in the "street food paradise" of Kuala Lumpur.
Bourdain explores the mixing of food, culture and politics in Istanbul, where he eats a Turkish breakfast and watches an oil wrestling match.
Bourdain and Charleston, S.C., resident Bill Murray dine on traditional Gullah cuisine, oyster pie, and shrimp and grits.
Highlights of the best and most delicious moments from Season 6. Also: a preview of Season 7.
Season 5 begins with Bourdain returning to South Korea after 10 years to experience the nuances of hyper-modern Seoul and sample Korean fried chicken, vintage "army" stew, and kimchi.
Bourdain visits Miami and tastes cow foot soup in "Little Haiti," and gets a lesson in the sights and sounds of the city from Questlove, Willie Clarke and Iggy Pop.
Bourdain visits Glasgow, Scotland, and gets a lesson in knife defense techniques. Also: a trip to the Scottish Highlands to sample some deep-fried haggis.
Bourdain explores Madagascar and visits the capital city of Tana. He also samples local cuisine with film director Darren Aronofsky.
Bourdain visits his home state of New Jersey with his brother Chris and enjoys fried hot dogs. Later, he goes to Atlantic City to take in the sights, sounds and good eats at the shore.
Bourdain explores Budapest where he samples goulash, fisherman's soup, blood sausage and chicken liver.
Bourdain explores a lesser-known side of Hawaii and enjoys a meal at an ancient oceanside fish pond with travel writer Paul Theroux and chef Andrew Le.
Bourdain explores Beirut.
Canada is explored by rail with Montreal chefs Dave McMillan and Fred Morin.

Anthony Bourdain travels to Iran and explores Tehran and Isfahan. Also: visits to Imam Square, the Borje Milad, mosques and caravanserai.

The Season 3 opener features a visit to Punjab, India, where the host samples items from roadside restaurants, a Sikh celebration and a community vegetarian eatery.

Bourdain takes the Grand Express train to St. Petersburg and explores the drinking and dining scene with famed Kremlin critic Boris Nemtsov.
A visit to Mississippi includes stops at Jackson's Big Apple Inn, a civil-rights-era eatery, and a juke joint in the Mississippi Delta.
